posts.name: Alper
posts.cooked: We want to use swerve drive, we are the Turkey team and we don’t have a lot of finances. We want to make a swerve chassis. We are looking for suitable and cheapest equipments. We need different ideas. Can you suggest me the most suitable and cheapest equpiments. Thanks.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Cheapest will be to use a CIM or other brushed motor for rotation and a SPARX MAX + NEO for drive. You can use a CIM for drive, but I don’t know if any commerical swerve modyles supports a CIMcoder right now.

The REV swerve module is currently the cheapest, and you will need to get a 550-size motor to rotate it if you want to save money there. They use a NEO550 but an RS550 or RS540 of some flavor would work too.

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked: I’d love it someone could test it in hardware but from what it looked like in CAD CIMs don’t work in Rev modules.

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked: The CIM is 2.52" OD, but clearance on the MaxSwerve motor mount is 2.50" (line to line).

posts.name: Aiden S
posts.cooked:
Only 20 thou? Slap that sucker on a lathe and you’re golden! /ˢ ᵇᵗʷ

link_counts.title: Weirdest FRC related things you own?

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
You did not indicate what modules you were thinking of using. If you are planning to use COTS modules, I think there is a lot of good discussion on other threads about the relative cost of each.

Since you only asked about the motors, I’m assuming that you already have modules or intend to build them yourself. If you are using COTS modules, then you may be limited to particular motor types by the module design itself (For example, the SDS and WCP modules are designed around using CIM class motors for both drive and steering. The REV module is designed for a a NEO for drive and a 550 class motor for steering (But not necessarily a NEO550).

Prior to 2019, we ran our swerve modules (custom) with a miniCIM for drive and a RS550 for steering. This works fine. So, in general, you do not need brushless motors to run swerve.

You will need to have an absolute encoder for steering control if you do not have a brushless motor.

We were able to get our design to successfully operate without an encoder on the drive motor. You have to make an assumption about the relationship between motor power and motor speed which is not very accurate. But, you will also find that the contact between the wheel and the floor is adequate to ensure that the wheel speed for each module does, in fact track with the motor power well enough to drive. It is not great, but we drove swerve for several seasons without a drive speed encoder. It is important to note that you will not be able to any real odometry unless you add an encoder somewhere on the drive motor system.

If you are able to afford brushless motors that have built-in encoders, then you get the encoder functionality for free. This could allow you to remove the absolute encoder from the module if you want to. In order to drive this way, you will have to manually align the modules before powering up the robot each time you want to drive it. We were forced into this situation in 2020 when our absolute encoders were not working and we still managed to win that event.

posts.name: Alper
posts.cooked: We are planning to manufacture the module ourselves. Thank you for your advices

posts.name: Aiden S
posts.cooked: It could’ve been, but doing what I said above is definitely 100% illegal. Please don’t lathe your motors lol
